questions.text:
45-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with repetitive activity and improves with rest. She also reports more pronounced symptoms in the evening. Neurological examination shows normal deep tendon reflexes. Workup reveals positive anti-MuSK antibodies and negative anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies.
Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of her condition?

choices.text: T-cell mediated destruction of anterior horn cells
Autoantibodies disrupt clustering of acetylcholine receptors
Disruption of post synaptic voltage-gated calcium channels
Inhibition of acetylcholine release from synaptic vesicles

questions.solution:
Correct answer is option B: Autoantibodies disrupt clustering of acetylcholine receptors

Anti-MuSK antibodies in myasthenia gravis impair the regulation and clustering of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, disrupting efficient nerve-to-muscle signaling. This leads to muscle weakness, especially with repetitive activity.

Option C is wrong as voltage gated calcium channels are present pre-synpatically and are not post synpatically. Morever they are not involved in M.Gravis.

Option A describes motor neuron disease. Option D implies pre junctional defect. 

Antibody Involvement

Antibody

Target

Effect

Anti-AChR antibodies

Acetylcholine receptors

Blocks transmission & reduces receptors

Anti-MuSK antibodies

Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK)

Disrupts receptor regulation and stability

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, especially affecting her speech and swallowing. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Her blood tests are negative for acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies. Which of the following antibodies is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is B: Anti-MuSK antibodies

MuSK is essential for clustering AChRs at the neuromuscular junction. Anti-MuSK antibodies are found in AChR-negative patients, often presenting with bulbar muscle weakness (affecting speech and swallowing).

 

Autoantibodies in Myasthenia Gravis

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness due to disrupted neuromuscular transmission.

Types of Autoantibodies

Autoantibody

Target

Effects

Associated Features

AChR antibodies

Acetylcholine receptors (AChR) on the postsynaptic membrane

Blocks signal transmission, leading to muscle weakness

Most common

MuSK antibodies

Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK)

Impairs AChR clustering and maintenance

Found in AChR-negative patients; associated with bulbar muscle weakness (speech, swallowing, chewing issues)
  • Diagnostic Tests
    • Repetitive Nerve Stimulation: Shows a decremental response (decline in muscle activity with repeated stimulation), indicating faulty neuromuscular transmission.
    • Blood Tests: Detect the presence of AChR and MuSK antibodies.

 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies (Option A): Seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not associated with neuromuscular transmission issues.

 

Anti-TPO antibodies (Option C): Linked with autoimmune thyroid disorders (e.g., Hashimoto’s thyroiditis).


Anti-Ro antibodies (Option D): Found in Sjogren’s syndrome and neonatal lupus, not relevant to myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman who is known case of myasthenia gravis presents to the clinic with worsening symptoms, including difficulty in lifting her arms and shortness of breath. On examination, you notice that her eyelids are drooping, and she has double vision. What is the most significant risk associated with her current condition if not addressed promptly?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is Option C: Respiratory Failure 

Respiratory failure is the most significant risk in a patient with myasthenia gravis, especially when muscle weakness affects the respiratory muscles. This can lead to inadequate ventilation, making it a critical and life-threatening condition that requires immediate intervention to prevent severe complications. Evaluate FVC and if the value is <15–20 mL/kg or there’s hypercapnia, immediate ICU admission is needed for possible ventilatory support.

Impaired vision (Option A): While double vision is concerning, it is not immediately life-threatening.

Aspiration due to swallowing difficulties (Option B): This is a risk but secondary to the more critical concern of respiratory failure.

Muscle atrophy (Option D): This is a long-term consequence of disuse and not an immediate risk in the acute setting.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the ER with acute muscle weakness, double vision, and difficulty swallowing. He has a history of myasthenia gravis and has been experiencing increased fatigue over the past few days. Which of the following clinical features would best help differentiate a myasthenic crisis from a cholinergic crisis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Response to edrophonium

Explanation:

Myasthenic crisis is characterized by severe muscle weakness that responds to edrophonium administration, while a cholinergic crisis does not improve or can worsen.  The question is more from academic perspective. Clinically speaking we can use bedside pulmonary function tests, clinical judgment, and pupillary exam which will show miosis in cholinergic crisis but will be normal in M.Crisis. 

Features of a Myasthenic Crisis

  • Severe respiratory muscle weakness: Critical for ventilation; can lead to respiratory failure needing immediate support.
  • Exacerbation of existing MG symptoms: Includes worsening ptosis, diplopia, and difficulty with chewing, swallowing, and speaking.
  • Rapid progression: Unlike typical MG, a myasthenic crisis can develop quickly over a short time.

 

Myasthenic Crisis vs. Cholinergic Crisis

Feature

Myasthenic Crisis

Cholinergic Crisis

Cause

Exacerbation of MG

Excessive anticholinesterase use

Symptoms

Severe muscle weakness, respiratory failure

Fasciculations, paralysis, small pupils (Options A & B ruled out)

Other Signs

-

Pallor, sweating, excessive salivation (Option D ruled out)

Diagnosis

Response to edrophonium test (Option C)

Can confirm cholinergic origin

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with symptoms of fluctuating double vision and drooping eyelids that worsen through the day. On neuro-examination DTRs are normal and power of all muscle groups except ocular muscles is normal. Blood tests confirms the presence of Anti-MuSK antibody What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate high-dose corticosteroids as the first-line treatment
Recommend immediate thymectomy regardless of symptom severity
Start anticholinesterase medications and consider immunosuppressants if symptoms persist
Advise the patient to undergo regular monitoring without any treatment

questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Start anticholinesterase medications and consider immunosuppressants if symptoms persist.

Anticholinesterase medications, such as pyridostigmine, are the first-line treatment for ocular myasthenia gravis, as they help improve neuromuscular transmission and alleviate muscle weakness. If symptoms continue despite initial treatment, immunosuppressants may be considered to reduce autoantibody production and improve outcomes.

Rarely, pyridostigmine may worsen symptoms (particularly if the ptosis is already severe), possibly due to excess cholinergic stimulation → increased eyelid fatigue or paradoxical neuromuscular junction desensitization.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, particularly affecting her eyelids and causing double vision. She also has difficulty in swallowing and develops dysarthria after speaking continously for few minutes. Which of the following diagnostic tests would confirm the suspicion of Myasthenia Gravis?

choices.text: Single Fiber EMG showing increased Jitter
Nerve conduction velocity showing slowed conduction of impulses

questions.solution:
Answer is A: Single fiber EMG showing increased jitter 

Best test for diagnosis of M.Gravis is single fiber EMG showing a increased jitter. Increased jitter means increased variable time between action potentials. It implies poor efficiency of neuromuscular transmission. 

Ice pack test is a initial screening test. Tensilon test is now reserved for diagnosis of difficult to diagnose cases.

NCV is done for diseases of nerves while we need to investigate NMJ disorder.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with diplopia that develops daily in evening hours along with difficulty in swallowing. On examination left eye ptosis is noted. Ice pack test shows improvement in ptosis . Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. The report of antibody panel is awaited. Which of the following will not be useful in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer-A) Physostigmine

This is a case of M.Gravis as diurnal variation of neuro-symptoms is seen and ice pack test shows resolution of ptosis. 

Physostigmine crosses the blood brain barrier and has central action. It has no role in managment of disorder of peripheral nervous system. Pyridostigmine is an anticholinesterase drug that is specifically used to increase acetylcholine activity at the neuromuscular junction, making it the most appropriate treatment for this patient. IVIg and PLEX would be required if this pateint develops M. Crisis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man known case of  myasthenia gravis presents to the emergency department with severe muscle weakness and respiratory distress. On examination he is using accessory muscles of respiration, spO2 on room air is 85% and he cannot speak full sentences. ABG shows pH: 7.2, pC02 50 mm Hg and HCO3= 27 meq/L.  Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for immediate management of this patient's condition?

choices.text: High flow nasal cannula and IVIg

questions.solution:
Correct answer is Option B: Endotracheal intubation and IVIg 

Diagnosis is M.Crisis and  administration of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) is an appropriate and immediate treatment for myasthenic crises as it rapidly reduces harmful antibody levels and improves muscle strength and respiratory function.  Since the pateint is having CO2 retention and is having signs of respiratory distress, intubation is also required. 

When to intubate in case of M. Crisis 

1. Clinical signs of respiratory distress:

  • Use of accessory muscles

  • Paradoxical breathing

  • Inability to speak full sentences

  • Labored breathing

2. Objective parameters:

  • Forced vital capacity (FVC) < 15–20 mL/kg

  • Negative inspiratory force (NIF) < −20 cm H₂O

  • PaCO₂ > 45 mmHg or PaO₂ < 60 mmHg on room air

  • Rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI) > 105

3. Bulbar weakness:

  • Dysphagia, weak cough, pooling of secretions

  • Risk of aspiration

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness, dry mouth, and absent tendon reflexes. He has a history of smoking. Electrophysiological testing reveals post-tetanic potentiation of motor response to nerve stimulation at a frequency of 20–50/sec. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option B: 3,4-Diaminopyridine

  • The patient's symptoms and diagnostic findings of incremental response on high frequency stimulation are consistent with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome. 
  • This condition is characterized by muscle weakness, autonomic dysfunction, and impaired neurotransmitter release due to antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels.
  • 3,4-Diaminopyridine is the most appropriate treatment as it enhances neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction, improving muscle strength.

How does 3,4-Diaminopyridine work in LEMS? 

  1. Blocks voltage-gated potassium (K⁺) channels on the presynaptic nerve terminal.

  2. This prolongs the depolarization of the presynaptic membrane.

  3. Prolonged depolarization keeps voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs) open longer.

  4. As a result, more calcium (Ca²⁺) enters the presynaptic terminal.

  5. Increased intracellular calcium leads to enhanced release of acetylcholine (ACh) into the synaptic cleft.

  6. This improves neuromuscular transmission and alleviates symptoms of muscle weakness

Lambert-Eaton Syndrome (LEMS)

Aspect

Details

Definition

A condition causing muscle weakness due to impaired transmission across the neuromuscular junction, similar to myasthenia gravis.

Types
  • Inflammatory
  • Paraneoplastic (associated with underlying malignancies, particularly small-cell lung cancer).

Pathophysiology

Antibodies to presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels impair transmitter release, unlike myasthenia gravis, which involves antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors.

Symptoms
  • Muscle weakness
  • Autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth)

Key Clinical Sign

Absence of tendon reflexes, which may return after sustained contraction of the affected muscle.

Diagnostic Testing

Electrophysiological testing showing post-tetanic potentiation of motor response to nerve stimulation at a frequency of 20–50/sec is indicative of LEMS.

 

Treatment Options:

Treatment

Mechanism/Use

3,4-Diaminopyridine

Enhances neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction.

Pyridostigmine

Increases acetylcholine levels, improving neuromuscular transmission.

Immunosuppression

Reduces immune response against voltage-gated calcium channels.

questions.text: 50 year old woman presents with complaints of arm weakness and diplopia. The symptoms tend to improve in evening hours. On examination ptosis is noted in left eye and DTR reflexes are absent. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows decremental response at low frequency stimulation. Which of the following is correct about this patient?

choices.text: Pre junctional defect affecting P/Q voltage gated calcium channels
Antibodies Target clustering of Ach receptors

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Pre junctional defect affecting P/Q voltage gated calcium channels 

The clinical profile of muscle weakness improving with day progresssion , arreflexia and repetitive nerve stimulation showing decremental response at low frequency stimulation is diagnostic of Lambert Eaton myaesthenic syndrome. Note that Repetitive nerve stimulation shows incremental response at high frequency stimulation in this condition.  The condition is associated with lung cancer and is a prejunctional defect. Option B, C are seen in M.Gravis. Option D is wrong as efficiency of neuromuscular transmission is reduced. \
